Telescope For Student Use
Warrants A Higher Priority
Ever since the construction of Mudd Hall
precipitated the demolition of the small
observatory on the freshman quad, both
graduates and undergraduates have been
denied access to a telescope on the
Homewood campus. For students attending
the University that will house the Space
Telescope Center, this is an insult.
Up until twelve years ago, the huge
telescope that formerly sat in the freshman
quad and which is owned by the Physics
Department was used only sporadically by
Hopkins students. Since then, however, with
the establishment of both undergraduate and
night school courses in astronomy, the
telescope has received much greater usage.
While this 92-year-old telescope is not of high
enough quality to be used for graduate
research, it is more than adequate for use as
a teaching instrument. Requiring students to
learn astronomy only by reading books while
a functional telescope lies dismantled in the
basement of Rowland Hall waiting for acceptance to some museum, is a disservice to
the Hopkins student body.
With the coming of the Space Telescope
Center to the Homewood campus, there will
undoubtedly be a greater emphasis placed on
astrophysics within the the Physics Department. This was indicated by the Christ Committee report on the future of the Arts and
Sciences division. The next several years will
likely see more enrolling undergraduates who

receive more University money, then one of
the priority expenditures should be a new
observatory and telescope for student use.
However, this still leaves the short-term
problem unsolved. There is no telling when
or even if a new observatory and telescope
will be installed. In the meantime there is a
need for a telescope available for student use.
True, there are smaller telescopes available
that allow viewing of the stars and planets,
yet it would be of invaluable benefit to current students to temporarily reassemble the
old telescope. The cost of building a new
makeshift observatory, similar to the one on
the freshman quad, with a sliding rooftop, I
would probably not be too expensive. This
should be done until a new permanent
system is installed.

What's The Matter
With Grades At JHU
BY BRIAN TISSUE
Nobody likes grades; professors don't like giving them
and students don't like getting
them. But some type of grading
system is necessary to satisfy
two needs: to provide the motivation for students w work
hard, and to measure the performance of students. Various
types of grading systems have
been tried, such as written
evaluations (Bennington College), but letter grades remain
the best alternative.
Over the last 20 years, the
average GPA at Hopkins has
risen from about 2.2 to nearly
3.1. Departments vary; some
now give a large percentage of
B's while the worst inflators
hand out A's like candy. For
the 1982 spring semester, the
percentage of A's given in the
following departments, based
on data soon to be published in
the Course Guide, are listed:
Military Science, 95 percent;
Behavioral Biology, 72 percent;
Mechanics, 66 percent; Writing
Seminars, 63 percent; Near
Eastern Studies, 60 percent;
and Classics, 59 percent. The
large percentage of A's these
and other departments hand
out defeats the purpose of
grades. They hardly measure a
student's performance, and
provide no incentive for superior work. Also, students will
choose electives in such departments only to inflate their
GPAs, to the detriment of
students who choose tougher
subjects. What is needed is a
University-wide grading policy
that would not only equalize
the different departments, but
also deflate grades overall.
The question that now arises
is, what should these grades be
based upon? They can't be
handed out arbitrarily; this
wouldn't measure a student's
accomplishments. They are often based on the professor's
standards, which is good in that
it provides sufficient motivation for students to work hard.
The fault of this system lies in
the nonuniformity of standards
set by different professors. One
year a class might receive all A's
and B's, and the next year a different professor might give a
class of equal quality all C's.
Obviously, the most consistent and fairest way to grade a

student is by comparison with
his peers. This means distributing grades by means of a curve
based on the class average.
Curves are not perfect; they are
unfair for small classes where
large gaps can be left in the
grade distribution. In these
cases, grades should be decided by the professor's standards,
which are often based upon an
imaginary curve of past students' performances. Another
problem with curves is't hat they
create competition among students, which detracts from the
learning process; competing for
the grade becomes more important than striving for knowledge. However, whether a person is competitive or not, learning to deal with competition
now is probably better than being faced with it later in the job
market and being unable to
cope with it.
The University needs to set
grading guidelines. A policy for
classes of 20 or more students
would operate along the following lines: 15 percent A's; 30
percent B's; 45 percent C's; and
10 percent D's; with failures
only given rarely. This would
decrease disparity between
departments, and also deflate
grades.
If grades were deflated at
Hopkins, compensation would
be necessary to make comparisons with students from
other institutions possible. This
could be accomplished by adding two things to transcripts.
First, academic information on
the students as a group would
be needed to establish the quality of undergraduates at Hopkins.
President Muller tells every
freshman class how great they
are with lots of statistics, and
surely information of this type
is available for the graduating
class. Also needed on the tran.scripts would be the grading
guidelines outlined above, the
average GPAs of the class as a
whole, and the average GPAs
of the students in the appropriate major. This would
make comparison of a student
with' his peers possible to give
an accurate measure of his accomplishments. The above proposal would create fairer, more
meaningful grades without putting Hopkins graduates at a
disadvantage. It could even
start a trend.

Usually, the training day began at
3:30 a.m. From 3:30 to 5:00 we readied
ourselves and our barracks for inspection. Then we ate breakfast and marched to training. After roll call and inspection, we had physical training (P.T.).
During P.T., the Black Hats saw to
it that we maintained the degree of
physical fitness necessary for the rigors
of military parachuting.
Next was the parachute training itself,
which continued despite temperatures in
excess of 96 degrees. Frequent trips to
water, both to drink and to wet down
our uniforms, saved most of us from
heat injury.
Before Jump Week arrived, we had
already executed all the basic jump
techniques, thanks to the training apparatus. During Ground Week, we were
exposed to the mock door, from which
we jumped three feet into a sawdust pit.
On the 34-foot tower, we were attached to pulleys that brought us down thick
metal cables to the ground, enabling us
to jump from the door, count and feign
checking our canopy while falling
through the air. We also learned how to
execute a Parachute Landing Fall
(P.L.F.) with the aid of another pulley
and cable apparatus called the lateral
drift device.
During Tower Week, we perfected
our P.L.F.'s and did more training on
the 34-foot tower. We also learned how
to control our chutes on a device that
suspended us in the air from our
parachute harnesses.
Finally, we were hoisted, parachute
and all, to the top of a 250-foot tower
and dropped. We were expected to control our parachutes properly and make
good P.L.F.'s. During Jump Week, we
were taken up for each of our five jumps
in one of three airplanes, two propeller
driven (C-130 and c-123), and one a jet
(C-141). All of us were determined to
complete all five jumps, and thus earn
our wings. Some of us hid injuries to do
SO.
At graduation, members of the First
American Airborne platoon, who had
graduated from training 41 years earlier,
spoke about the proud tradition of the
Paratrooper. At the end of the ceremony, we snapped to attention with a
thunderous,"Airborne," and the Black
Hats pinned on our wings.

What's The Matter
With Grades At JHU
BY BRIAN TISSUE
Nobody likes grades; professors don't like giving them
and students don't like getting
them. But some type of grading
system is necessary to satisfy
two needs: to provide the motivation for students w work
hard, and to measure the performance of students. Various
types of grading systems have
been tried, such as written
evaluations (Bennington College), but letter grades remain
the best alternative.
Over the last 20 years, the
average GPA at Hopkins has
risen from about 2.2 to nearly
3.1. Departments vary; some
now give a large percentage of
B's while the worst inflators
hand out A's like candy. For
the 1982 spring semester, the
percentage of A's given in the
following departments, based
on data soon to be published in
the Course Guide, are listed:
Military Science, 95 percent;
Behavioral Biology, 72 percent;
Mechanics, 66 percent; Writing
Seminars, 63 percent; Near
Eastern Studies, 60 percent;
and Classics, 59 percent. The
large percentage of A's these
and other departments hand
out defeats the purpose of
grades. They hardly measure a
student's performance, and
provide no incentive for superior work. Also, students will
choose electives in such departments only to inflate their
GPAs, to the detriment of
students who choose tougher
subjects. What is needed is a
University-wide grading policy
that would not only equalize
the different departments, but
also deflate grades overall.
The question that now arises
is, what should these grades be
based upon? They can't be
handed out arbitrarily; this
wouldn't measure a student's
accomplishments. They are often based on the professor's
standards, which is good in that
it provides sufficient motivation for students to work hard.
The fault of this system lies in
the nonuniformity of standards
set by different professors. One
year a class might receive all A's
and B's, and the next year a different professor might give a
class of equal quality all C's.
Obviously, the most consistent and fairest way to grade a

student is by comparison with
his peers. This means distributing grades by means of a curve
based on the class average.
Curves are not perfect; they are
unfair for small classes where
large gaps can be left in the
grade distribution. In these
cases, grades should be decided by the professor's standards,
which are often based upon an
imaginary curve of past students' performances. Another
problem with curves is't hat they
create competition among students, which detracts from the
learning process; competing for
the grade becomes more important than striving for knowledge. However, whether a person is competitive or not, learning to deal with competition
now is probably better than being faced with it later in the job
market and being unable to
cope with it.
The University needs to set
grading guidelines. A policy for
classes of 20 or more students
would operate along the following lines: 15 percent A's; 30
percent B's; 45 percent C's; and
10 percent D's; with failures
only given rarely. This would
decrease disparity between
departments, and also deflate
grades.
If grades were deflated at
Hopkins, compensation would
be necessary to make comparisons with students from
other institutions possible. This
could be accomplished by adding two things to transcripts.
First, academic information on
the students as a group would
be needed to establish the quality of undergraduates at Hopkins.
President Muller tells every
freshman class how great they
are with lots of statistics, and
surely information of this type
is available for the graduating
class. Also needed on the tran.scripts would be the grading
guidelines outlined above, the
average GPAs of the class as a
whole, and the average GPAs
of the students in the appropriate major. This would
make comparison of a student
with' his peers possible to give
an accurate measure of his accomplishments. The above proposal would create fairer, more
meaningful grades without putting Hopkins graduates at a
disadvantage. It could even
start a trend.

Usually, the training day began at
3:30 a.m. From 3:30 to 5:00 we readied
ourselves and our barracks for inspection. Then we ate breakfast and marched to training. After roll call and inspection, we had physical training (P.T.).
During P.T., the Black Hats saw to
it that we maintained the degree of
physical fitness necessary for the rigors
of military parachuting.
Next was the parachute training itself,
which continued despite temperatures in
excess of 96 degrees. Frequent trips to
water, both to drink and to wet down
our uniforms, saved most of us from
heat injury.
Before Jump Week arrived, we had
already executed all the basic jump
techniques, thanks to the training apparatus. During Ground Week, we were
exposed to the mock door, from which
we jumped three feet into a sawdust pit.
On the 34-foot tower, we were attached to pulleys that brought us down thick
metal cables to the ground, enabling us
to jump from the door, count and feign
checking our canopy while falling
through the air. We also learned how to
execute a Parachute Landing Fall
(P.L.F.) with the aid of another pulley
and cable apparatus called the lateral
drift device.
During Tower Week, we perfected
our P.L.F.'s and did more training on
the 34-foot tower. We also learned how
to control our chutes on a device that
suspended us in the air from our
parachute harnesses.
Finally, we were hoisted, parachute
and all, to the top of a 250-foot tower
and dropped. We were expected to control our parachutes properly and make
good P.L.F.'s. During Jump Week, we
were taken up for each of our five jumps
in one of three airplanes, two propeller
driven (C-130 and c-123), and one a jet
(C-141). All of us were determined to
complete all five jumps, and thus earn
our wings. Some of us hid injuries to do
SO.
At graduation, members of the First
American Airborne platoon, who had
graduated from training 41 years earlier,
spoke about the proud tradition of the
Paratrooper. At the end of the ceremony, we snapped to attention with a
thunderous,"Airborne," and the Black
Hats pinned on our wings.
